3.13.1.title: Purpose
3.13.1.content:
**Why Drills Matter:**
- Build automatic responses
- Verify crew competency
- Identify equipment issues
- Maintain readiness
- Meet regulatory requirements

**Key Principle:**
A well control event is not the time to learn procedures. Drills ensure the crew can respond effectively when it matters.

3.13.2.title: Types of Drills
3.13.2.content:
**Pit Drill:**
- Simulate pit gain
- Test detection and initial response
- Verify monitoring systems
- Quick drill, minimal disruption

**BOP/Shut-In Drill:**
- Practice shut-in procedure
- May include actual BOP operation
- Test crew coordination
- Time and evaluate response

**Scenario Drill:**
- Full well control scenario
- Includes kill sheet completion
- May simulate entire kill operation
- Tests decision-making

**Trip Drill:**
- Practice tripping shut-in
- Include FOSV installation
- Different starting positions

**Diverter Drill:**
- Practice shallow gas response
- Diverter activation
- Evacuation procedures

3.13.3.title: Frequency
3.13.3.content:
**Minimum Requirements:**
- Weekly: At least one drill type
- Per tour: New crew members participate
- Each crew: Both crews must drill

**Typical Schedule:**
- Pit drill: Weekly
- Shut-in drill: Weekly, rotating scenarios
- Full scenario: Monthly or per well section
- Trip drill: Before major trips
- Diverter drill: When diverter is primary equipment

**Regulatory:**
- Specific requirements vary by jurisdiction
- May specify minimum types and frequency
- Document all drills

3.13.4.title: Conducting Drills
3.13.4.content:
**Planning:**
- Select drill type and scenario
- Brief drill conductor
- Ensure equipment available for drill
- Choose appropriate time (not during critical operations)

**Execution:**
1. Announce drill (or unannounced for realism)
2. Start scenario (simulate kick indication)
3. Crew responds per procedures
4. Observe and time response
5. Note actions taken
6. Complete drill when objectives met

**Debrief:**
- Review performance with crew
- Discuss what went well
- Identify areas for improvement
- Answer questions
- Positive reinforcement for good performance

3.13.5.title: Evaluation Criteria
3.13.5.content:
**Response Time:**
- Time from indication to shut-in
- Target: < 2 minutes typical
- Compare to previous drills

**Correct Procedure:**
- Proper sequence followed
- Right equipment used
- Communication appropriate

**Equipment:**
- All equipment functioned
- Any issues identified
- Positioning correct

**Team Performance:**
- Coordination effective
- Communication clear
- Leadership appropriate
- All roles understood

3.13.6.title: Documentation
3.13.6.content:
**Record:**
- Date and time
- Drill type and scenario
- Participants
- Response time
- Actions taken
- Evaluation (pass/needs improvement)
- Issues identified
- Follow-up actions

**Use of Records:**
- Track crew performance over time
- Identify training needs
- Demonstrate competency for audits
- Support continuous improvement

**Form:**
Use standard drill record form (Appendix B)

3.13.7.title: Improving Drill Value
3.13.7.content:
**Vary Scenarios:**
- Different operations (drilling, tripping, connections)
- Various influx types
- Complications (stuck pipe, equipment failure)
- Time of day variations

**Involve All Levels:**
- Drillers lead drill floor response
- Supervisors practice decision-making
- Mud engineer practices kill mud calculation
- All crew members participate

**Learn from Each Drill:**
- Debrief after every drill
- Implement improvements
- Track recurring issues
- Recognize good performance

**Avoid:**
- Same drill every time (becomes routine)
- Skipping drills when busy (often when most needed)
- Negative feedback only (kills motivation)
